newsitem.title: GERMANY: Tourists to be moved from grounded German cruiser.
newsitem.headline: Tourists to be moved from grounded German cruiser.

text.p: A group of 149 tourists stranded aboard a German cruise ship that ran aground near King William Island in Canada's Northwest Passage last Thursday will be evacuated, the ship's Hamburg operator said on Wednesday.

Hanseatic Tours said that 120 of the mostly American and German passengers on board the cruise ship, the Hanseatic, would be transferred to the ice-breaker Captain Dranitsyn and continue their voyage on Thursday after attempts to refloat the ship had failed.
The 29 others had chosen to cut short their voyage and return home, the operator said.
Hanseatic Tours said in a statement that the ship had run into the sandy ground one km (half a mile) south of the King William island on August 29.
"The atmosphere on board is very good," the company said. "The temperature outdoors is four degrees (Celsius, 39 Fahrenheit)."
The passengers were able to take expeditions to the island during the last week, where they held barbecues, the company said.
On Thursday, they will be taken by small boats to a nearby air runway and will be airlifted in 40 minutes to Cambridge Bay.
From there 120 of them would be switched to the Captain Dranitsyn to continue their cruise while the others could head straight back home.
Three tow boats are on their way to try to pull the Hanseatic free of the sand barge, the operator added.
